The same folks who funded early internet research and stealth technology Boston Dynamics was founded in 1992 as a spin-off from MYT by Mark Ryber. But what really pushed them into global fame was partnering with DARPA in the early 2000s. DARPA wanted robots that could move like animals and humans, not just roll like machines. And Boston Dynamics delivered. Atlas, DARPA funded, designed, but DARPA's influence goes deeper. LS3, the legged squad support system. This was DARPA's dream of a robotic pack mule for soldiers. Standing as tall as a horse, LS3 could carry 400 lb of gear, travel 20 m on a full tank, and follow soldiers through forests and deserts by voice or GPS command. Soldiers could tell it to follow them or send it to a GPS spot on a map, and it would find its way there automatically using cameras and sensors to avoid rocks, trees, and ditches. In videos, you can watch it trot along behind a human leader, keeping perfect balance even when pushed or walking over uneven ground. DARPA wanted LS3 to be tough enough for real missions. Something that could travel up to 20 m in a day, handle any kind of weather, and last for about a full day on a tank of fuel. The idea was to give soldiers a reliable mechanical teammate that could carry their supplies and follow them wherever they went. But LS3 itself had an ancestor, a robot that kickstarted the entire journey. Launched in 2005 with DARPA funding, Big Dog was built to help soldiers carry heavy gear through tough terrain. About the size of a small mule, weighing around 110 kg, it could carry up to 150 kg of equipment. You could kick it or push it, and it would stumble, but quickly regain balance, almost like it had instincts. It could even climb steep slopes up to 35°, splash through water, or trot over ice without falling. Powering all this motion was a small gasoline engine running a set of hydraulic legs. But the humanoid story actually starts earlier with Petman. The protection ensemble test mannequin developed in 2009 to simulate human physiology for testing protective military gear like chemical suits. Standing about 1.75 m tall, weighing around 80 kg, Petman could walk, squat, kneel, and perform calisthenics, mimicking human movements and physiological responses like sweating and temperature regulation. Powered by hydraulic actuators with 29° of freedom, Petman was built to act as a human surrogate for environmental testing in hazardous conditions. It wasn't designed for autonomous tasks or complex environment interaction. It was a test bed, a proof of concept, and it became the foundation for Atlas. The same control systems, the same balance algorithms, the same understanding of bipedal locomotion, all built on Petman's back. It could zip between rows, pick up heavy boxes with its long arm, and neatly stack them onto pallets, all without a human's help. Its gripper used suction power to lift each box smoothly, almost like it had a giant vacuum hand. What made handle special was its balance as it bent, turned, or lifted.
